awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: A DLT Machine Learning Platform for Blockchain Warehousing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project improves the use of large-scale databases, data warehouses, and the software that used to commercially data-mine these resources.  In the era of big data, many applications, such as machine learning and artificial intelligence, critically rely on data functionalities including efficiency, interoperability, and analysis. However, their data subsystems are challenged to meet these needs due to multiple technical limitations, such as centralized storage, homogeneous data formats, and tightly coupled workflows. This STTR project will develop a new framework to overcome these limitations to improve big data applications in various scientific fields, such as biological sciences, astronomy, and computational chemistry.  At the end of this Phase I project, the requisite knowledge and foundational materials for developing a blockchain-based data warehousing middleware will be produced.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to advance the specific knowledge and commercialization of DLTs (Distributed Ledger Technologies) and blockchains by creating novel and innovative environments for further development for DLTs and blockchains as a "virtuous cycle", starting with bottlenecks identified in modern data warehouses. The DLT tool developed here advances blockchain protocols, specifically for removing quadratic and speculative costs from orthodox protocol-based approaches to blockchains on conventional hardware and instituting linearizable and constant costs with other innovative programming methods (e.g., probabilistic pruning). New statistical, topological, and computational approaches will be researched and developed for these purposes, including for development of techniques applicable for machine learning, artificial intelligence, peta-scale and exa-scale computing, advanced scientific computing, and pedagogical academic development of future generations. The expected results include a new set of protocols and a unified tool for integrating data types and multiple networks into conventional data warehouses, especially for advancement of data warehouses struggling to keep pace with new blockchain data, metadata, and real-time analytics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our Phase 1 STTR R&D activities were completed despite pandemic interference at federal and local levels, requiring team changes, schedules changes, vendor changes, and workload changes. Despite these hurdles the Phase 1 core Modules and their Tasks were completed with minimal internal delays. Preliminary Phase 1 investigations indicated that more real-world data are required for useful data warehouse sample sets to perform experiments upon; however, real-world data involving specialized financial sets, NFT marketplace scaping and metadata, and other financial real-world data outside of narrowly-defined and sparsely-available scientific data sets made for some setbacks during initial Phase 1 R&D, but some preliminary investigations into specialized financial sample data warehouses does indicate that these prototypical sample data warehouses could be further augmented into more tractable and data-aggregately more useful for Phase 2 R&D experimentation, specifically in how real-world data and their entailing conditions for processing strain and possibly break hardware underlying HPC and normative blockchain installations. In out subsequent R&D for future Phase 2 Tasks, we plan on tackling these hardware strains from real-world transactional behaviors by not only integrating these onto blockchains but also integrating those blockchains into orthodoxly specialized retirement funds and other financial sample data warehouses, thereby their extremal scalability up to rigorous computational, mathematical, and physical capacities and suggesting necessary alterations to our blockchain platforms to augment orthodox data warehouses into future-proofed financial infrastructure that can anticipate workloads typified only by emerging data lake architectures and hybrid multi-cloud platforming (e.g., emerging Sky Computing concepts).

Other outcomes were the aggregately yielded publications in-review or in-print now, as well as several repositories for aggregated code that had undergone or been novelly investing during R&D activities. New blockchain protocols also have been researched and developed during these R&D activities, several of which have been reported in the aforementioned multiple publications. 


Last Modified: 10/09/2022
Modified by: Mohammad Sadoghi
